case_name: Civil Appeal Nos. 736 to 739, 91-3 and 1621 of 1968

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 736 to 739, 91-3 and 1621 of 1968 filed before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 736 to 739, 91-3 and 1621 of 1968. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 2, 1964 of the Calcutta High

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated December 2, 1964 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 131 of 1961 etc.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 2, 1964 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 131 of 1961 etc. Jagdish Swarup, Solicitor-General, T.A. Ramachandran, N. Sachthey and B.D. Sharma, for the appellant

facts.text: Proceeding for assessment to Income-tax for the year 1949-50 involving respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In a proceeding for assessment to Income-tax for the year 1949-50 the respondents in these appeals claimed that the dividend distributed by the Ukhra Estate Zamindaries Ltd. was exempt from tax,

facts.text: Respondents claimed that dividend distributed by Ukhra Estate Zamindaries Ltd. was exempt from tax as not from accumulated profits.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents in these appeals claimed that the dividend distributed by the Ukhra Estate Zamindaries Ltd. was exempt from tax, because the fund out of which the dividend was distributed did number form part of the accumulated profits of the Company.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the contention and brought the dividend to tax in hands of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytention and brought the dividend to tax in the hands of the respondents. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that Rs. 1,12,500 out of a total amount of Rs. 2,24,000

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 1,12,500 out of total Rs. 2,24,000 distributed by Company represented capital gains arising on or after April 1, 1948, exempt from tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that Rs. 1,12,500 out of a total amount of Rs. 2,24,000 distributed by the Company, represented capital gains arising to the Company on or after April 1, 1948 and number being dividend within the meaning of s. 2 6A of the Income Tax Act, 1922, the share distributed to the shareholders out of that amount was exempt from income-tax.

facts.text: Tribunal reversed the order of Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was reversed in appeal by the Tribunal. In the view of the Tribunal the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  in force in the year of assessment was number exhaustive,

facts.text: Tribunal held that definition of dividend in s. 2(6A) was not exhaustive and ordinary dividend chargeable under general charging section.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Tribunal the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  in force in the year of assessment was number exhaustive, and if the amount distributed was dividend in ordinary parlance it became chargeable under the general charging section, and that clause 2 6A  was companycerned with deemed dividends, and exclusion of certain capital gains by the proviso had numberbeating on the issue raised by the revenue

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under s. 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act: Whether Rs. 28,125 rightly included as dividend in total income of assessee for 1949-50?

anchor.surface_text: The following question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court of Calcutta .under s. 66  1   of the Indian Income-tax Act Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 28,125 was rightly included as dividend in the total income of the assessee for the assessment year 1949-50?

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: was answered in the negative. The Commissioner has appealed to this Court. with certificates granted by the High Court. Dividend in its ordinary companynotation means the sum paid to or received by a share- holder proportionate to his share holding in a companypany

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Supreme Court with certificates granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner has appealed to this Court. with certificates granted by the High Court. Dividend in its ordinary companynotation means the sum paid to or received by a share- holder proportionate to his share holding in a companypany out of the total sum distributed.

facts.text: Company distributed total amount of Rs. 2,24,000 as dividend.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner held that Rs. 1,12,500 out of a total amount of Rs. 2,24,000 distributed by the Company, represented capital gains arising to the Company on or after April 1, 1948

facts.text: Rs. 1,12,500 out of distributed amount represented capital gains arising to Company on or after April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that Rs. 1,12,500 out of a total amount of Rs. 2,24,000 distributed by the Company, represented capital gains arising to the Company on or after April 1, 1948 and number being dividend

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that proportionate share of capital gains is exempt from tax under s.12 as dividend income.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the proportionate share of the capital gains out Of which the dividend was distributed to the shareholders of the Company must be deemed exempt from liability to pay tax under s. 12 as dividend income liable to tax.

facts.text: Capital gains arising after March 31, 1948 excluded from accumulated profits for definition of dividend in s.2(6A).

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that the expression accumulated profits, wherever it occurs in this clause, shall number include capital gains arising before the I st day of April 1946 or after the 31st day of March, 1948. Dividend distributed by a Company being a share of its profits

facts.text: No contention raised before Tribunal or High Court that exempt dividend liable as other income.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Revenue sought to argue that share of dividend which is number chargeable to tax by virtue of the exemption clause is still liable to tax as income other than dividend. But numbersuch companytention was raised before the Tribunal or the High Court

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs. One hearing fee.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts. One hearing fee.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, Ag. C.J.

anchor.surface_text: Barman Ranjit Ghose and Sukumar Ghose, for the respondents  in all the appeals . The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, Ag. C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the definition companytained in s. 2 6A  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, in the year of assessment 1949-50 was as follows Dividend includes--  a  any distribution by a companypany of accumulated profits whether capitalised or number, if such distribution entails the release by the companypany to its shareholders of all or any part of the assets of the companypany Explanation.--The words accumulated profits wherever they occur in the clause, shall number include capital profit Provided further that the expression accumulated profits, wherever it occurs in this clause, shall number include capital gains arising before the I st day of April 1946 or after the 31st day of March, 1948.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 28,125 was rightly included as dividend in the total income of the assessee for the assessment year 1949-50?

anchor.surface_text: under s. 66  1   of the Indian Income-tax Act Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 28,125 was rightly included as dividend in the total income of the assessee for the assessment year 1949-50?

issues.text: Whether the definition of dividend in s. 2(6A) in force in the year of assessment was not exhaustive, such that amounts distributed as dividend in ordinary parlance are chargeable under the general charging section despite exclusion by the proviso?

anchor.surface_text: the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  in force in the year of assessment was number exhaustive, and if the amount distributed was dividend in ordinary parlance it became chargeable under the general charging section, and that clause 2 6A  was companycerned with deemed dividends,

issues.text: Whether capital gains arising after the 31st day of March, 1948 fall within accumulated profits for the purpose of the definition of dividend under s. 2(6A)?

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the definition companytained in s. 2 6A  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, in the year of assessment 1949-50 was as follows Dividend includes--  a  any distribution by a companypany of accumulated profits whether capitalised or number, if such distribution entails the release by the companypany to its shareholders of all or any part of the assets of the companypany Explanation.--The words accumulated profits wherever they occur in the clause, shall number include capital profit Provided further that the expression accumulated profits, wherever it occurs in this clause, shall number include capital gains arising before the I st day of April 1946 or after the 31st day of March, 1948.

issues.text: Whether share of dividend which is not chargeable to tax by virtue of the exemption clause is still liable to tax as income other than dividend?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Revenue sought to argue that share of dividend which is number chargeable to tax by virtue of the exemption clause is still liable to tax as income other than dividend. But numbersuch companytention was raised before the Tribunal or the High Court and numberquestion was raised in that behalf. We will number be justified in entering upon the question which was number raised or argued before the Tribunal and before the High Court.

arguments.claim: Definition of dividend in s. 2(6A) not exhaustive; distribution that is dividend in ordinary parlance chargeable under general charging section; s. 2(6A) concerned only with deemed dividends; proviso exclusion of capital gains has no bearing on revenue's issue.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was reversed in appeal by the Tribunal. In the view of the Tribunal the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  in force in the year of assessment was number exhaustive, and if the amount distributed was dividend in ordinary parlance it became chargeable under the general charging section, and that clause 2 6A  was companycerned with deemed dividends, and exclusion of certain capital gains by the proviso had numberbeating on the issue raised by the revenue

arguments.court_reasoning: No warrant for 'deemed dividends only' view; treats excluded gains as ordinary dividend nullifies proviso; strained construction.

arguments.claim: Share of dividend not chargeable to tax by virtue of exemption clause still liable to tax as income other than dividend.

arguments.court_reasoning: No such contention or question raised before Tribunal or High Court; not justified to entertain at Supreme Court stage.

arguments.claim: Dividend in ordinary connotation is sum paid/received by shareholder proportionate to shareholding out of total sum distributed.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner has appealed to this Court. with certificates granted by the High Court. Dividend in its ordinary companynotation means the sum paid to or received by a share- holder proportionate to his share holding in a companypany

arguments.claim: Distribution out of capital gains does not impress capital gains character/attributes on dividend in hands of shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: Dividend distributed by a Company being a share of its profits declared as distributable among the shareholders, is number impressed with the character of the profits from which it reaches the hands of the shareholder. It would be therefore difficult to hold that the mere fact that a distribution has been made out of the capital gains, it has the attributes of capital gains in the hands of the shareholders.

arguments.claim: Proviso expressly excludes capital gains arising after March 31, 1948 from accumulated profits and thus from dividend definition.

anchor.surface_text: But that does number assist the case of the Revenue, for the Legislature has expressly excluded from the companytent of dividend, capital gains arising after March 31, 1948. The proviso to the Explanation clearly enacted that capital gains arising-after March 31, 1948 are number liable to be included within the expression dividend.

arguments.claim: Inclusive definition does not permit treating expressly excluded capital gains as still falling within dividend chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The definition is, it is true, an inclusive definition and a receipt by a shareholder which does number fall within the definition may possibly be regarded as dividend within the meaning of the Act unless the companytext negatives that view. But it is difficult on that account to hold that capital gains excluded from the definition of dividend by express enactment still fall within the charge of tax.

arguments.claim: Under s. 2(6A), only proportionate share from accumulated profits excluding capital gains in excepted period is taxable dividend component.

anchor.surface_text: According to the definition in s. 2 6A  of the Income-tax Act only the proportionate share of the member out of the accumulated profits  excluding capital gains arising in the excepted period  distributed by the Company, alone will be deemed the taxable companyponent.

arguments.claim: No warrant for view that s. 2(6A) definition only covers deemed dividends.

anchor.surface_text: There is number warrant for the view expressed by the Tribunal that the definition of dividend only includes deemed dividend.

arguments.claim: Interpreting excluded capital gains as not within s. 2(6A) definition but still taxable as ordinary dividend nullifies proviso; strained construction not warranted.

anchor.surface_text: To hold that the capital gains within the excepted period are number part of the accumulated profits for the purpose of the definition under s. 2 6A  and a distributive share thereof does number on that account fall within the definition of dividend and therefore of income chargeable to tax and still to regard them as a part of accumulated profits for the purpose of dividend in the popular companynotation and to bring the share to tax in the hands of the shareholders is to nullify an express provision of the statute. We do number see any reason why such a strained companystruction should be adopted.

arguments.claim: Proportionate share of capital gains from which dividend distributed is exempt from tax under s. 12 as dividend income.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the proportionate share of the capital gains out Of which the dividend was distributed to the shareholders of the Company must be deemed exempt from liability to pay tax under s. 12 as dividend income liable to tax.

holdings.text: The proportionate share of the capital gains out of which the dividend was distributed to the shareholders of the Company must be deemed exempt from liability to pay tax under s. 12 as dividend income liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.2(6A) proviso excludes post-1948 capital gains from accumulated profits, hence not dividend; proportionate share exempt as dividend income under s.12.

holdings.text: Capital gains arising after March 31, 1948 are not liable to be included within the expression dividend.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of proviso to Explanation in s.2(6A) expressly excludes such capital gains from accumulated profits and thus from dividend definition.

holdings.text: There is no warrant for the view that the definition of dividend only includes deemed dividend; to regard excluded capital gains as ordinary dividend nullifies the proviso and is a strained construction not to be adopted.

Section 12 exemption in c6 directly addresses i4 on whether exempt dividend share is liable to tax as other income.
